articles.title: Southwest Airlines moves to assigned seats, adds premium cabin with more legroom, redeye flights
articles.description: Southwest Airlines is moving from its famously open seating to assigned seats, adding a premium cabin with more legroom and adding redeye flights.
articles.content:
The Dallas-based carrier will share more comprehensive details in September.

After 53 years offering passengers the ability to choose their own seats, Southwest Airlines is ushering in a new era for ... [4093 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines has announced a new era in its boarding process, moving to assigned seats and offering premium seating on all flights after 53 years of open seating. The Dallas-based airline will also add a premium cabin with more legroom and more seating options. The move is part of a comprehensive upgrade to the Southwest experience and aims to transform customer experience and improve financial performance. The airline has not specified when the changes will go into effect, but plans to provide more details at its Investor Day in late September. The company conducted extensive operational testing and found that 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat. Booking on initial routes is available starting Thursday, with the first overnight flights set to arrive on Valentine's Day 2025 in five initial nonstop markets.

articles.authorsByline: GISELA SALOMON, ASTRID SUÁREZ, TERESA MEDRANO, NAYARA BATSCHKE
articles.title: Forced to emigrate, Venezuelans living abroad hope for change — and to eventually return home
articles.description: The prolonged economic and political instability in Venezuela has forced millions of Venezuelans to leave over the past decade, quashing many of their dreams and leaving many wondering if they’ll ever return to what was once South America’s most prosperous country.
articles.content: The prolonged has forced millions of Venezuelans to leave over the past decade, quashing many of their dreams and leaving many wondering if they’ll ever return to what was once South America’s most pr... [8658 symbols]
articles.summary: The Venezuelan government has been under pressure for a decade, leading to the largest exodus in Latin America's recent history. The refugee agency UNHCR estimates that over 7.7 million Venezuelans have left, mostly in the Americas, ranging from Colombia and Brazil to Argentina and Canada. Most have settled in Colombia, where the government has integrated them into the formal economy. Some have found new lives and hope to return to Venezuela someday. Meanwhile, some Venezuelans are voting for President Nicolás Maduro, who is seeking a third term, against former diplomat Edmundo González.

articles.title: 'Prepare for a bloodbath' in the airline industry: Panel
articles.description: American Airlines (AAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) shares were initially under pressure in Thursday's pre-market hours after reporting earnings, both seeing a bump higher at the start of regular trading hours. American and Southwest signaled margin headwinds tied to airfare prices and capacity pressures. Boyd Group International President Mike Boyd and Bloomberg Intelligence senior aerospace, defense, and airlines industry analyst George Ferguson come onto The Morning Brief to talk about the state of the airline industry and how these travel conditions could shape the landscape in the latter half of 2024. "Prepare for a bloodbath the rest of the year," Boyd tells Yahoo Finance, his sentiments affirmed by Ferguson's belief that capacity numbers could make it "rough to turn 3Q around, 4Q is always a weak quarter. It's going to be a rough year for the airlines, rougher than I thought." For more expert insight and the latest market action, click here to watch this full episode of Morning Brief. This post was written by Luke Carberry Mogan.

The companies indicated potential margin headwinds due to rising airfare prices and capacity pressures. Boyd Group International President Mike Boyd and Bloomberg Intelligence senior aerospace, defense, and airlines industry analyst George Ferguson discussed the state of the airline industry on The Morning Brief. Boyd predicts a 'bloodbath' in the industry, with Ferguson stating that capacity numbers could make it difficult to turn 3Q around and 4Q is always a weak quarter.

articles.description: JetBlue eliminated some flights from Florida last month but the airline announced it's adding more later this year and in 2025.
articles.content:
JetBlue adding new flights from Florida to New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Maine. Here's where

JetBlue has announced it's adding new Florida flights, bringing their totals up to more than 225 daily flig... [2176 symbols]
articles.summary: JetBlue is expanding its Florida flights to more than 225 daily flights, bringing them to include New Hampshire, Rhode Island, and Maine. The expansion comes after JetBlue cut some routes in Florida, including eight routes from Fort Lauderdale and a Miami-Los Angeles flight. The biggest additions will be to New England states, with Manchester-Boston Regional Airport in New Hampshire adding daily flights to Orlando and Fort Myers and Fort Lauderdale starting in 2025. Rhode Island's T.F. Greene Airport in Providence will also get winter seasonal flights to Fort Myers, Tampa, and Portland International Jetport in Maine. JetBlue plans to begin flights from Long Island MacArthur Airport daily to Orlando, and four times a week to Fort Lauderdale, and West Palm Beach.

articles.content:
The Boeing whistleblower who killed himself earlier this year was so distressed by working conditions at its South Carolina plant that he suffered PTSD, his lawyer has claimed.

John Barnett, 62, was ... [11576 symbols]
articles.summary: Boeing whistleblower, John Barnett, was so distressed by working conditions at its South Carolina plant that he suffered PTSD, according to his lawyer Brian Knowles. Barnett, who was diagnosed with PTSD and anxiety after being exposed to a hostile work environment, took his life during a legal battle with the carrier in March. His death came during a break in depositions in his own whistleblower retaliation suit against Boeing. The revelation comes a month after his family filed a lawsuit against Boeing, holding the company responsible for his death. Barnett had previously warned about sub-standard parts being fitted to aircraft on the assembly line and had issued warnings about the 787 Dreamliner and 737 Max models before his sudden death.

articles.title: Currensea vs Monzo: which is the best?
articles.description: Telegraph Money helps you decide which debit card you should take on holiday
articles.content: If you’re looking for the best card to use while on holiday, Monzo and Currensea are two options you may have come across. Both cards let you enjoy fee-free spending and cash withdrawals abroad, which... [7139 symbols]
articles.summary: Monzo and Currensea are two options for the best travel payment cards for holiday season, with both allowing for fee-free spending and cash withdrawals abroad. Monzo, an app-only “challenger” bank, was introduced in 2015 as a prepaid card and has since received a full banking licence, attracting over nine million British customers. It is easy to open an account with Monzo and is subject to a "soft" credit check, which gives Monzo an assessment of how well you manage your credit, unlike a hard credit check required for borrowing. However, in countries outside of the European Economic Area, you can only withdraw up to £200 worth of cash every 30 days if you withdraw more than this, a 3pc fee is required. CurrenSea's card is linked to an existing bank account, but may still carry out a soft credit check when applying for a new account. Monz's card can be added to your Apple Pay or Google Pay wallet, and users can spend using it anywhere in the world that accepts card payments without paying any fees or charges at all. Curransea's card also converts transaction amount to British pounds using the interbank exchange rate. The company's premium plan costs £25 a year and costs £100 per year, while its premium plan includes a 0.5pc foreign exchange rate and airport lounges.

articles.title: Paris has overestimated its appeal – and bargain-hunters could benefit
articles.description: The Olympic Games tourism boom hasn’t materialised – now hoteliers and Airbnb owners are frantically cutting their rates
articles.content: The 2024 Olympic Games in Paris officially begins this Friday with a dazzling opening ceremony where 10,000 athletes from across the globe will sail down the River Seine. But with reports showing tick... [2047 symbols]
articles.summary: The 2024 Olympic Games in Paris is officially starting with a dazzling opening ceremony, with 10,000 athletes from across the globe expected to participate. However, ticket sales are reportedly at an all-time low, suggesting that British fans may enjoy a summer of sport in the French capital. With around 600,000 tickets still available, bargain hunters may find a better deal due to the availability of last-minute tickets. Many hotels in Paris, including Ibis hotels, were expecting to profit from bookings during the Games and have reportedly doubled their prices, hoping to capitalise on sports fans' interest in the summer Games. Despite these price hikes, the expected demand has not materialised. From July 20-September 8, the cost of a single Metro ticket will increase from €2.15 to €4, bus tickets will double, and the Louvre admission price has already been increased by nearly 30% this year.

The video, which has over 2.8 million views and 256,000 likes on the TikTok platform, was viewed as a "influencer moment" but ended in a disaster when she slipped into the water. The viral video has received over 930 comments from amused social media users, many calling it relatable and inspiring. However, there are concerns about the effects of over-tourism on Lake Como, which can erode historic buildings and damage seabeds, and make it difficult for locals to find affordable housing. In April, the mayor of Como City, Alessandro Rapinese, was reportedly considering introducing a Venice-style tourist tax to reduce the footfall. In 2019, the Italian government approved a proposal for a 5-euro entry fee for tourists visiting Venice, but its rollout was delayed until spring 2024 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The incident occurred after police were alerted to a fight at the airport and when they responded, three officers were punched to the ground in a violent assault. One officer has been removed from duty pending a review by the Independent Office of Police Conduct (IOPC).

articles.title: Do not use Manchester Airport incident for political purposes, Burnham warns

articles.summary: Andy Burnham, the Labour mayor of Greater Manchester, has warned against exploiting the Manchester Airport incident for political gain. This comes after a police officer was filmed apparently stamping on a man's head at the airport. After the clip was widely shared online, hundreds of protesters gathered outside a Rochdale police station and chanted "Allahu Akbar". Labour MPs have also raised concerns with senior officers in Greater Manchester Police regarding the incident. Burnham stated that he would work with the Independent Office for Police Conduct to ensure a high level of neutrality in its investigation. His comments came as Akhmed Yakoob, a lawyer who ran as an independent at the election on a pro-Gaza ticket, released a video of himself with two men arrested at Manchester Airport.

RAC Breakdown spokesperson Alice Simpson warned of potential breakdown or accident due to faulty vehicles.

articles.title: Park board members say Blue Line light rail crossing could endanger cyclists, pedestrians in north Minneapolis
articles.description: Some on the  Minneapolis park board wants the Met Council to go back to the drawing board to preserve the Grand Rounds.
articles.content: A proposed light-rail station in north Minneapolis means more than 200 trains will cross the treasured Grand Rounds bike and pedestrian trail every day — a prospect that deeply concerns some members o... [6791 symbols]

entities.data: the Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board

articles.summary: A proposed light-rail station in north Minneapolis could potentially endanger cyclists and pedestrians, according to some members of the Minneapolis Park and Recreation Board. The Lowry Station, located at the Minneapolis-Robbinsdale border, is part of the $3.2 billion Blue Line extension project, which will connect downtown Minneapolis to Brooklyn Park beginning in 2030. The Park Board was expected to vote on a letter to the Metropolitan Council expressing concerns about the station's street-level design and whether the planning body can legally build a light-Rail line through parkland. Some park board members suggest a safer design could include a tunnel under the Wirth/Victory Memorial Parkway Regional Trail portion of the Grand Rounds network or relocate the station closer to North Memorial Health in Robbinsdale. The initial plan for the Lowry station featured an aerial bridge for light-ra trains and an elevated station above the West Broadway and Lowry Avenue bridges. However, after strong concerns were raised by Park Board commissioners and others, the project's planners discarded the design and started over.

articles.title: McDonald's says Japan glitch was not tied to CrowdStrike outage
articles.description: “This feels like episode of Mr. Robot,” one user said on social media as McDonald's kiosks went down
articles.content: The massive outage was caused by a mishandled software update from cybersecurity firm CrowdStrike. The glitch has caused major disruptions for numerous industries and companies, including airlines lik... [2137 symbols]
articles.summary: McDonald's Japan has reported a systems outage that was unrelated to the CrowdStrike outage, caused by a mishandled software update from cybersecurity firm. The issue affected the chain's cash registers, forcing only Teriyaki and McChicken sandwiches to be ordered using cash. McDonald's is investigating the cause and a timeline for recovery is unclear. This is not the first time McDonald's has faced a system outage this year, following a similar issue in March which forced the chain to close locations in Japan, Australia, and the UK. Starbucks is also being affected by the outage, with roughly 82% of users reporting an inability to order via the coffee chain's app.

The event included over 20 local producers showcasing their produce, including wines, cheeses, blossom teas, tangy salts and condiments. It was part of a first step to boost business for the islands' local producers and showcased their produce in a gathering of sectors. The showcase also provided insights into the efforts of craft companies and cooperatives dedicated to preserving local traditions and customs. The Regional Ministry for Tourism, Culture and Sport is supporting projects through the REVIVE Project, Next Generation EU Funds, and the Sustainable Tourism Tax, which enables projects aimed at research, innovation, sustainable development, and circular economy.

articles.summary: London-based experiential art and design studio Studio Grant Harvey has created a concept for Tiffany's first cruise ship, the Tiffany Jewel, using artificial intelligence software Midjourney. The ship's interiors are inspired by the sinuous forms of ocean waves and features sculptural art installations such as the Tiffany Eternal Bloom sculpture in the Grand Atrium and the Tiffany Tapestry of Seduction in the Sapphire Lounge. The Grand Theatre features advanced LED-embedded crystal panels, Hologauze screens, 360-degree projection mapping, 3D audioscape, and HYPERVSN state-of-the-art holographic technology. The hotel also features a bejeweled leather-bound roulette wheel and walls adorned with Tiffany's signature blue.

The Maryland Transportation Authority, which owns the Chesapeake Bay Bridge in Annapolis, said in the months after the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March ...

keywords.name: several ongoing Bay Bridge capital projects

entities.data: the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Reconstruction Advisory Group

articles.summary: The Maryland Transportation Authority, which owns the Chesapeake Bay Bridge in Annapolis, is exploring pier protection for the Bay Bridge following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in March. The initial budget for the project is $145 million. The authority is likely to decide on "physical" pier protection improvements by the end of the year or early 2025, with a target completion date of 2027-28 winter. The older span, built in 1951, has about 15 to 20 years of useful life left, according to Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld. The Coast Guard and National Transportation Safety Board have launched investigations into the risks of such infrastructure at 11 domestic ports.

articles.summary: Greater Manchester's mayor, Andy Burnham, has criticised Reform UK MP Lee Anderson for his response to a video showing a police officer kicking and stamping on a man's head. The footage, which circulated online, appeared to show a uniformed male officer holding a taser over the man before striking him twice. Anderson defended the police officers, stating they faced a "clear risk" and should be commended. However, Burnham called Anderson's comments "irresponsible" and called the footage "very disturbing". An officer has been suspended over the incident at Manchester Airport. The incident sparked a protest outside Rochdale police station and chants of "shame on you" were heard. Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said there was now a process following the officer's suspension.

Mountain rescue volunteers, Search and Rescue Dog Association members and coastguard have been involved in an extensive search. Police are appealing for information about Betts' whereabouts and for information regarding her whereabouts.

DALLAS — Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.

The airline said Thursday that... [3487 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines plans to abandon its tradition of assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom. The airline, which has been studying seating options for over 50 years, is making the changes due to shifting passenger preferences. The changes could generate revenue and improve financial performance. The announcement comes as both Southwest Airlines and American Airlines reported a significant drop in Q2 profit, with both companies reporting higher costs and reduced pricing power. The company's second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier to $367 million, largely due to higher costs for labor, fuel, and other expenses. The change comes as Southwest Airlines is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management, which argues that the airline lags behind in financial performance and has failed to change with the times.

articles.summary: Former cruise ship chef Alan Bills, who claimed to have been left with crippling tinnitus after falling on broken pavement near Whitstable home in 2017, claimed he tripped where tree roots broke the pavement resulting in his bizarre ear injury. However, he later abandoned his claim and was declared "fundamentally dishonest" by a judge at Canterbury County Court in 2022. The judge found that the accident never happened and declared him as "fundamentalally dishonest". He has now been given an eight-month suspended prison sentence for contempt of court. The claim was part of a witness statement from Peter Nicholson, who initially claimed he saw the fall and rushed over to help and call for an ambulance, but was later found to be untrue.

articles.summary: A wildfire has destroyed part of the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, in the province of Alberta, causing significant loss to buildings. The town and Jasper National Park, which houses over two million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday when there were 15,000 visitors. The fire is one of hundreds currently burning across Alberta and British Columbia, and Environment Canada is predicting 10 mm to 20 mm of rain for Thursday. The federal government warned in April that this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada. The Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can transport 890,000 barrels per day, is a major focus for help.

articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is ending open seating and offering extra legroom seats on its airplanes, marking the largest change in its history in 53 years. The airline plans to start selling the first flights offering additional legroom next year and will also begin overnight flights starting in February. The change comes amid increased pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management to segment its product like other airlines after he disclosed a nearly $2 billion stake in Southwest. Southwest's CEO Bob Jordan argued that the change was the right time for the airline and that 80% of its own customers prefer an assigned seat. However, no changes were made to its two free checked bags policy.

It will also offer redeye flights for the first time, starting from February 14, 2025 in nonstop markets such as Las Vegas to Baltimore, Los Angeles to Baltimore and Nashville; and Phoenix to Baltimore. The changes are in response to customer preferences changing, with more customers taking longer flights and wanting an assigned seat. The company has also been dealing with an issue of carbonated drink cans rupturing mid-flight, causing 20 reported employee injuries.

Prosecutors alleged that Jafari’s company received about $26 million in task orders under an architectural and engineering contract while Macrina served as commissioner. Chief 11th Circuit Judge William H. Pryor Jr. stated that the jury instruction Kish claimed should have been given at trial seemed to be a "misstatement of the law". The Supreme Court recently clarified that whether a gift is a bribe or a gratuity depends on when someone agrees to accept it in exchange for a favor.

The aim is to achieve by the end of the year by 63% to 67% without major delays. The company's CEO, Richard Lutz, anticipates an improvement in punctuality in the second half of 2018. Rail travel across Germany has been hampered by industrial strikes, poor infrastructure, and unexpected weather events. High-speed ICE 4 trains will be prioritized for short-term maintenance work so they can quickly return to service.

articles.title: Climate protest causes major disruption at Germany's largest airport
articles.description: Germany's Frankfurt airport faced serious disruption on Thursday, with more than one in 10 flights at the major European transport hub cancelled after activists from the Last Generation climate group glued themselves to runways. The protest led to the cancellation of about 170 of the 1,400 scheduled flights at Germany's largest airport, operators Fraport said. Passengers were told to expect delays for the rest of the day. The runways were clear for flight operations to resume at 7:50 am (0550 GM
articles.content: Emergency vehicles from the police, fire department and airport security are parked on the apron of Frankfurt Airport, where two activists have taped themselves up. Several demonstrators had forced th... [3760 symbols]
articles.summary: Germany's largest airport, Frankfurt Airport, was hit by a major disruption on Thursday, with over one in 10 flights cancelled due to activists from the Last Generation climate group who forced their way onto the airport grounds and stuck themselves to runways. The protest led to the cancellation of about 170 of the 1,400 scheduled flights at Germany's largest, Fraport, and resulted in a temporary suspension of air traffic. The airport has since resumed operations, with passengers advised to expect delays throughout the day. The activists were handed to Hesse state police after being removed from the tarmac. The group claimed responsibility for the disruption, calling for an end to fossil fuel use by 2030. Hesse State Premier Boris Rhein criticised the action, calling it "irresponsible and criminal climate radicals" who caused significant damage to holidaymakers. Transport Minister Volker Wissing and Cabinet decided to tighten penalties for air traffic interference, but parliament still needs to vote on the proposal.

articles.summary: The Economist Intelligence Unit's annual Global Liveability Index has revealed that the world's most liveable cities have settled into a new normal, with the average liveability score barely increasing over the past year. Four European cities and four Asian-Pacific cities made the top 10, with Toronto dropping from the top ten due to a housing crisis. The top 10 also remained remarkably similar to last year's rankings. Vienna, Austria, won the title of world's Most Liveable City for the third consecutive year, scoring perfect scores in four out of five categories, including public transport, healthcare, culture and environment, and numerous universities. Residents expressed their love for living in their cities, particularly in Vienna where tap water comes from the mountains and its cuisine is influenced by Bohemia, Hungary and Italy. Zurich was recently named the world’s Smartest City due to its technological infrastructure and commitment to sustainability.

articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is discontinuing its open seating model for the first time, replacing it with assigning seats before all flights and offering premium seating options. The move is part of the airline's strategy to improve financial performance, increase its stock price, and enhance customer experience. Since its launch 57 years ago, the airline has had an open seating policy, which allows passengers to choose their seats once they board their flight. Research revealed that 80% of customers and 86% of potential customers prefer an assigned seat system, and the number one reason a passenger chooses a competitor is the open model. The airline also plans to introduce premium seating with extended legroom, with potentially up to one-third of a cabin being allocated to this type of seat. The changes were announced on the same day as Southwest reported a significant drop in profits for the second quarter of the year.

A shoplifting bird dubbed "Steven Seagull" has been banned from a convenience store for flying off with packets of crisps over a six-year stealing spree.

Staff at the Lyndale Central store in Wyke Re... [570 symbols]
articles.summary: A shoplifting bird named "Steven Seagull" has been banned from a convenience store in Wyke Regis, Dorset, for six years. Staff at the Lyndale Central store in the area have put up posters urging customers to "close the door" behind them in an effort to stop Steven. The manager of the store, Stuart Harmer, revealed that Steven had stolen about 30 packets of crisps in the past two months alone.

articles.title: Stocks making the biggest moves premarket: American Airlines, Honeywell, RTX, Ford and more
articles.description: These are the stocks posting the largest moves in premarket trading.

articles.summary: Shares in American Airlines fell 6% after the airline issued weak profit guidance for the third quarter, with the company expecting unit revenue to drop as much as 4.5% due to oversupply. Shares of Honeywell also fell nearly 5% despite a second-quarter report that beat expectations. Meanwhile, Hasbro surged more than 6% following raising its full-year guidance and beating forecasts. Shares also rose 3% after Q2 earnings topped estimates. Northrop Grumman's shares also climbed 3% following a top and bottom line beat for the second quarter and raising its forecast. Shares for International Business Machines also gained 3% as the tech company's quarterly results exceeded expectations. ServiceNow's stock jumped 6% in premarket trading after posting stronger than expected earnings.

articles.summary: Porthdinllaen, a seaside village in North Wales, has been identified as a cost-effective alternative to the picturesque Hout Bay in Cape Town, South Africa, for cost-saving holidays. The beachside destination is also known for its sandy beaches, rugged cliffs, and bustling harbours. The popular Morfa Nefyn Beach, home to the stunning Morfa-Nefyn beach, also offers a great spot for water activities such as kayaking and snorkelling. The Ty Coch Inn, a red-brick pub on the beach, is considered "world-class" and "magical" by patrons and is recommended by TripAdvisor. Dog owners are advised to leash their pets near the Ty Coch area.

articles.summary: Southwest Airlines has announced plans to end open seating and offer seats with extra legroom on its airplanes, in response to pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management. The move is part of a shift away from the airline's traditional business model and comes alongside its second-quarter earnings topping Wall Street estimates. The company plans to offer premium, extended legroom seats, accounting for roughly one-third of its fleet. It is also in discussions with Boeing about the financial impact of delayed jet deliveries.

articles.summary: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd. (RCL) has reinstated dividends after a four-year hiatus due to record demand. The company will pay a quarterly dividend of 40 cents per share, allowing stockholders to benefit from strong travel demand. Royal Caribbean halted its 78-cent payout in 2020 due to the industry shutdown. This strong growth has enabled the company to reach financial targets 18 months ahead of time. It also raised its full-year profit outlook for a third time this year to $11.35 to $10.45 per share.

articles.title: Wall Street slightly lower as airlines post earnings ahead of latest GDP report

Wall Street leaned toward losses before the opening bell Thursday as more earnings poured in while investors waited for the latest data on how the U.S. economy fared in the second quarter.

Futures fo... [4336 symbols]
articles.summary: Wall Street fell slightly before the opening bell as airlines and retailers reported strong second-quarter results. Southwest Airlines and American Airlines reported a significant drop in profit despite higher revenue. The airline also announced it was ending its 50-year-old practice of open seating and plans to offer premium seating for customers who want more legroom. Ford Motor Co. fell more than 13% in premarket after reporting that its Q2 net income fell 4.7% due to rising warranty and recall costs. Meanwhile, Warner Bros. jumped 9.4% after posting strong financial results that exceeded Wall Street expectations. The government is expected to release its first estimate of how the U.S. economy performed in Q2.

articles.title: Labour ministers accused of ‘jaw-dropping’ hypocrisy after using private jet
articles.description: Andrew Murrison said ministers had been ‘hopping on and off’ an Airbus A321 despite the party’s commitments to crack down on private jets.
articles.content:
A Conservative former minister has accused the Government of “jaw-dropping” hypocrisy after ministers used a private jet, despite the party’s commitments to crack down on their use.

Andrew Murrison c... [2327 symbols]
articles.summary: Conservative former minister, Andrew Murrison, has accused the Labour government of hypocrisy after ministers used a private jet, despite pledges to clamp down on their use. He accused the party of "jaw-dropping" hypocrisy, with ministers "hopping on and off" an Airbus A321 and asking if this was compatible with their aim of restoring trust in politicians. This follows Foreign Secretary David Lammy's use of the private jet earlier this week. Labour has previously criticised Tory ministers for using the plane, particularly in 2022 when the then-foreign secretary Liz Truss used it to travel to Australia. Commons Leader Lucy Powell responded by saying that the Prime Minister's travel arrangements are a security matter.

articles.summary: Travel company Rocket DMC Uzbekistan has successfully highlighted the significant tourism potential of Uzbekistan to travel agents in Turkey. The event was organised with the support of the Association of Travel Agencies of Turkey (TÜRSAB). Over 60 Turkish travel agencies and 10 representatives of the media were updated on Uzbekistan's unique culture and heritage. The interactive presentation included a video highlighting the history of the country, local art and cultural objects, and modern conditions for tourists. Turkish tour operators also received detailed information about the company's tour packages and airport services. The company hopes this will increase the number of Turkish tourists to Uzbekistan even more due to the successful meeting.

articles.title: Family of expat who died after doctors gave him Nolotil warn tourists
articles.description: Roy St Pierre, 77, had been cycling from his home in Portugal to see his family and newborn granddaughter in England when he was admitted to a hospital on the Costa Blanca with stomach pain.
articles.content: The family of a British grandfather who died after being given a painkiller that has been linked to dozens of tourist and expat deaths in Spain has spoken out to warn other Brits of the potentially de... [5082 symbols]

entities.data: the Association for Drug Affected People
the Hospital Universitari Sant Joan d'Alacant

articles.summary: The family of a British grandfather, Roy St Pierre, have warned other Brits of the potentially deadly side effects of Nolotil, a painkiller that has been linked to dozens of tourist and expat deaths in Spain. The drug, which is banned in the UK along with 40 other countries due to its risk of adverse side effects, has been known to wipe out patients' white blood cells and increase the risk of sepsis. Despite warnings about these side effects being popular with Spanish doctors as it is stronger than paracetamol and ibuprofen. Despite a government directive in 2018, campaigners claim that the drug has continued to be prescribed, often without the knowledge of the patient.

articles.title: Southwest breaks with 50-year tradition and will assign seats; profit falls at Southwest, American
articles.description: The airline said Thursday that it has been studying seating options and is making the changes because passenger preferences have shifted.  Airlines are struggling with higher costs and reduced pricing power, especially on flights within the United States, as the industry adds flights faster than the growth in travel demand.  The results met Wall Street expectations.
articles.content:
Southwest Airlines plans to drop its tradition of more than 50 years and start assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom.

The airline said Thursday that it has b... [3478 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines plans to abandon its tradition of assigning seats and selling premium seating for customers who want more legroom. The airline, which has been studying seating options for over 50 years, is making the changes due to passenger preferences shifting. The changes could generate revenue and improve financial performance. This comes as both Southwest and American Airlines reported a significant drop in Q2 profit, despite higher revenue. The second-quarter profit fell 46% from a year earlier to $367 million, due to higher costs for labor, fuel, and other expenses. American Airlines also reported a 46% drop in profit to $717 million and said it would break even in the third quarter, well below Wall Street expectations of 48 cents per share profit. The announcement comes as Southwest is under pressure from Elliott Investment Management, who argues that the airline lags behind in financial performance and wants to replace CEO Robert Jordan and Chairman Gary Kelly.

When do Florida school start in August? What to know before students go back

Florida students have less than three weeks to savor the rest of their summer vacation.

Starting Aug. 12, most of the sta... [2755 symbols]

articles.summary: The Florida school will start in August, with most students returning to classrooms on the first possible date of the 2024-2025 school year on Aug. 12. The Florida Back-to-School Sales Tax Holiday will take effect across the state starting on Monday, July 29. The National Center for Education Statistics lists the minimum 180 days of school for Florida students, a time typical across the country, and Florida does not require a minimum number of hours per school day. New legislation signed by Gov. Ron DeSantis in 2023 will require later start times for middle and high schools throughout Florida, with middle schools barred from starting the “instructional day” earlier than 8 a.m., while high schools will be barred from beginning the school day before 8:30 am.

articles.summary: The Hong Kong Shopping Festival, organised by the Trade Development Council (TECD), will be held from August 1 to 31 by the Chinese Manufacturers’ Association to promote local consumer products and brands on mainland Chinese e-commerce and social media platforms. The event will also be held at the AsiaWorld-Expo to attract mainland visitors. Over 230 Hong Kong brands are expected to participate in the campaign. The festival will feature six major product categories, including apparel and accessories, personal care and cosmetics, home and living; traditional foods; smart gadgets; and health supplements. All consumers at the festival will receive a 10% discount, while elderly shoppers will receive tailored recommendations for products. The second phase of the campaign will include live-streaming sessions on major e-Commerce and social networking platforms.

articles.title: Man Suffers Third-Degree Burns to Feet After Losing Flip-Flops in Death Valley

articles.content:
A man who went for a walk in the sand dunes in California’s Death Valley is recovering after suffering third-degree burns to his feet, park officials said.

The National Park Service (NPS) said in a p... [2926 symbols]
articles.summary: A man from Belgium, 42, who went for a walk in the sand dunes in California's Death Valley, is recovering after suffering third-degree burns to his feet. The National Park Service (NPS) reported that he lost his flip-flops during a walk and had to be rescued due to the heat. Park rangers had to transport the man to a hospital due to his severe burns and pain. However, there was difficulty as Mercy Air's helicopter couldn't land safely in the area due to extreme heat conditions. The NPS issued an "extreme summer heat" danger alert for Death Valley and warned of high temperatures of 100°F to 130°F. They also advised visitors to plan ahead to prevent heat-related illnesses like heat rash and heat stroke, which can lead to brain damage or injury vital organs.

articles.title: A Southwest flight came 150 feet from crashing in the sea. Experts suspect 'pure human error.'
articles.description: A Southwest flight is being investigated after it flew dangerously close to Tampa's Courtney Campbell Causeway.
articles.content: A Southwest Airlines flight that was diverted after a dangerously low descent was likely down to "pure human error," aviation experts said.The Boeing 737 Max departed from Columbus, Ohio, on July 14 a... [3802 symbols]
articles.summary: A Southwest Airlines flight was diverted after it dropped to 150 feet above the sea, causing it to be diverted to Fort Lauderdale. Aviation experts believe this was due to "pure human error" as the Boeing 737 Max departed from Columbus, Ohio, and was headed to Tampa, Florida. Richard Curran, a professor of Aviation Management at City University of London, and Mark Stephens, a retired Delta Air Lines pilot, warned that the aircraft should have been at least 1,000 clear of the water and its "dangerously low" position could have a disastrous impact. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the cause of the incident. This is not the first time a Southwest flight has dropped to a dangerously low altitude; in June, a plane was found to have dropped to 525 feet when it was 9 miles from landing in Oklahoma City.

Southwest is getting rid of open seating and will now assign seats After more than 50 years, Southwest Airlines... [1912 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is moving away from its open seating policy, replacing it with assigned seating and will instead assign seats. The airline, which has been operating open seating for over 50 years, plans to introduce premium seating options on all flights and introduce red-eye flights. The change is part of several major operational changes, with the airline hoping this will appeal to both new and existing customers and increase its appeal to customers. The move to assigned seating is part part of a larger effort to enhance the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value without sacrificing operational efficiency. Booking for the airline's new red-eyes flights has opened.

It's the end of an era at Southwest Airlines.

After more than 50 years, the airline is getting rid of its open seating policy.

In a press release Thursday, the Dallas-based airline acknowledged "pre... [1748 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is ending its open seating policy, which has been in place for over 50 years. The airline plans to switch to assigned seating and streamline its boarding process to appeal to both new and existing customers, with four out of five preferring assigned seats. This is part of several major operational changes, including introducing premium seating options on all flights and introducing red-eye flights. While specific cabin layout details are still in design, Southwest expects roughly one-third of seats across the fleet to offer extended legroom, in line with industry peers. The changes are designed to elevate the customer experience, improve financial performance, and drive shareholder value without sacrificing operational efficiency.

articles.title: "Transformational change": Southwest Airlines is doing away with open seating
articles.description: It marks a major shakeup to its business model.
articles.content: Southwest Airlines is shifting to assigned seating and will offer some premium seating with extra legroom, the low-cost carrier announced on Thursday as part of a significant shakeup to its traditiona... [2872 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is moving away from open seating and offering premium seating with extra legroom in a significant shakeup to its business model. The airline, which has been operating for 50 years, found that 80% of its customers and 86% of potential customers prefer assigned seating. The changes come as Southwest reported its second quarter results, which beat some expectations but fell short in other key areas. The company did not specify when the changes would go into effect but will provide more details in late September. The change comes amid criticism from an activist investor and $231 million in first-quarter losses, and a series of potentially dangerous incidents.

articles.title: Freediving community pays tribute to "pioneering instructor" lost in spearfishing accident
articles.description: The second annual South Florida Freedive Fest honored well-known freediver Virgil Price III, who died in a spearfishing accident on Mother's Day.
articles.content:
An annual event that brings freedivers from around the world to Palm Beach County honored a former Palm Beach resident who died in a spearfishing accident on Mother's Day.

The second annual South Flo... [3325 symbols]
articles.summary: The second annual South Florida Freedive Fest, which brings freedivers from around the world to Palm Beach County, honored the late Virgil Price III, a former Palm Beach resident who died in a spearfishing accident on Mother's Day. The event was held July 10-15 at Phil Foster Park, Lake Park Marina and other locations throughout the county. Price, a graduate of the Benjamin School in North Palm Beach, was a "pioneering instructor" in the area who offered continuing education and training for freedivers. His body has not been recovered. The six-day festival featured 30 freedivers and featured a series of competitive and recreational events.

articles.title: What is Cathay’s alcohol, drugs policy? Post checks Hong Kong carrier’s manual
articles.description: Airline once again under scrutiny after junior pilot suspended over failed alcohol breath test before scheduled flight to Hong Kong from Sydney.
articles.content:
A Cathay spokesman said safety was the airline’s “overriding priority” and it had zero tolerance for staff who failed to comply with its alcohol and other drugs (AOD) policy.

The airline on Thursday ... [4962 symbols]

keywords.name: Hong Kong flag carrier Cathay Pacific Airways

articles.summary: Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacific Airways has come under scrutiny again after a junior pilot was suspended over a failed alcohol breath test before he was scheduled to fly to the city from Sydney. The airline confirmed that safety is its top priority and has zero tolerance for staff who violate its alcohol and other drugs policy. According to Cathay's operational manual, a breath test failure for employees in safety-sensitive roles can result in a reading greater than 9 micrograms of alcohol in 100ml of breath, which is stricter than Hong Kong's drink-driving limit. Pilots are prohibited from using cannabis, cocaine and other illicit psychoactive substances without a valid prescription. The company also advises pilots not to fly if they are dependent on medication, and never to immediately start a new medication.

articles.summary: Qantas passengers are being warned of cancellations and delays due to a six-hour strike by over 50 refuellers in the airline's supply chain at Sydney Airport on July 31. The strike comes after petrol company Ampol rejected an offer to provide fairer pay, better hours, and more full-time positions. The Transport Workers Union (TWU) will carry out the strike after 14 meetings with Ampol failed to reach a fair agreement. The disruption could cause widespread disruption as Ampol services 16 airlines including Qantas, Virgin, Jetstar, Air New Zealand, Delta and British Airways.

articles.summary: JetBlue Airways Corp. (Nasdaq: JBLU) is ending service to Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport (MSP) this fall, where it has operated a Boston-MSP route for over six years. The airline had entered the Minnesota market in 2017 and had served from Boston's Logan Airport to MSP's Terminal 2. It is also dropping 23 other routes nationally and ending service at a half-dozen airports. The changes will take effect in late October.

articles.title: Big Changes At Southwest: Assigned Seats, Red-Eye Flights And More
articles.description: The Dallas-based airline is shaking up some of its long-held protocols in an effort to please customers and stave off attacks from an activist investor.
articles.content:
or the first time in its half century of operations, Southwest Airlines is ditching its open seating and shifting to assigned seats, the company announced ahead of a quarterly earnings call Thursday.
... [3855 symbols]
articles.summary: Southwest Airlines is moving from open seating to assigned seats for the first time in its history, announcing major changes ahead of a quarterly earnings call. The airline will no longer allow passengers to fly with two free checked bags, while other U.S. carriers charge between $15 and $40 for the initial checked bag and between $40 and $60 for a second bag. The company will also offer overnight “red-eye” flights for its first time, which it claims will increase revenue and cost savings without additional aircraft capital deployment. Despite this, Southwest has been under pressure from Elliott Investment Management, a firm owned by Paul Singer, an activist investor who took a $1.9 billion stake in the airline. Elliott has also called for the ousting of Jordan and Gary Kelly, the company’s chairman and former CEO.

Unit revenue is expected to drop as much as 4.5% for the third quarter due to an overabundance of flights in a high-demand travel environment. The airline's CEO, Robert Isom, stated that the company had performed poorly in Q2 due to its sales strategy and an imbalance of domestic supply and demand. Shares for American fell 8% before regular trading in New York.

articles.summary: Luskentyre Beach on Harris Island in Scotland, known for its clear turquoise water and pristine white sand, has been likened to Australia's golden coastline. Travel expert Annabel Symonds believes that Luskentre Beach, which is also known as one of the best beaches in the world, resembles Australia's Queensland Beach. The beach is known for having a soft, powdery texture and comfortable for sunbathing and relaxing with a book. It is also a great place to observe wildlife, with sightings of dolphins, red deer or golden eagles. Luskentye Beach has been named one of Europe's most stunning beaches by Lonely Planet and has also been named the Beach of the Year in the Countryfile Magazine Awards.

articles.title: How did Sky Harbor get its name? Why the Phoenix airport is called that
articles.description: Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport consistently ranks among the best airports in the U.S. Here's how it got its distinctive name.
articles.content:
How did Sky Harbor get its name? Why the Phoenix airport is called that

Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport is one of the 10 busiest airports in the United States and it consistently ranks among... [2558 symbols]
articles.summary: Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, one of the 10 busiest airports in the United States, was named Sky Harbor by J. Parker Van Zandt, the owner of Scenic Airways in 1928. The name was originally used to identify a landing field for aircraft. The Wall Street Journal named the best airport in the country in 2023, and it also ranked highly for on-time performance and customer experience in a study released in 2024. The airport changed hands several times before being purchased by the city of Phoenix for $100,000 in 1935. This acquisition ensured the continued operation and development of Phoenix Sky Harbor Airport.

articles.summary: Budgeting for a Florida vacation can be difficult, especially if you don't know what city you're visiting. The cost of a week in Destin, Florida, is estimated at $2,683, with accommodations being the largest expense at $222 a day. St. Augustine, Florida's oldest city, is an excellent destination for exploring historical sites and museums. A one-week trip to Cape Canaveral for two people averages $3,078, largely due to higher costs for accommodations. A single-week vacation to Ocala averages $1,169, considerably cheaper than some Florida beach destinations. Orlando is one of Florida’s pricier destinations, with an average of $4,488 for a two-person trip.
